questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription.

You need to search the Microsoft Purview audit log by using PowerShell on a Windows device.

What should you do first?

choices.C: Install the Microsoft Exchange Online PowerShell module.
choices.A: Install the Microsoft Graph PowerShell module.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
ChatGTP: ðŸš€ Final Answer:

âœ… C. Install the Microsoft Exchange Online PowerShell module

Selected Answer: C
To search the Microsoft Purview audit log using PowerShell on a Windows device, the first step you should take is:

C. Install the Microsoft Exchange Online PowerShell module.

This is because you need to connect to Exchange Online PowerShell to use the Search-UnifiedAuditLog cmdlet, which is required for searching the audit log.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that uses Microsoft Defender for Endpoint.

You have the on-premises devices shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You are preparing an incident response plan for devices infected by malware.

You need to recommend response actions that meet the following requirements:

â€¢ Block malware from communicating with and infecting managed devices.
â€¢ Do NOT affect the ability to control managed devices.

Which actions should you use for each device? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

comments.content: I see a huge semantic issue here and I guess it's on purpose :) When you isolate a device or say you restrict app execution or what not you are in the 'containment' phase of an incident. So containment is a general term that can include different actions. The most obvious one would be the 'isolation' mode from Defender. This said you can isolate onboarded and non onboarded machines alike. One via the defender AV on the device blade and a couple of other places, the other one via the device inventory for non on-boarded devices. It cause a GPO to be sent to every onboarded machines that pushes a firewall run blocking incoming & outgoing access to the compromise not onboarded device, even if it changes its IP. Neat feature if you ask me :)
The link provided states that containment is only supported for Windows devices onboarded with defender.
In the link you provided it clearly states you can contain the device.

discussion.content:
Device 1 is managed by Defended so you can Isolate and investigate this device. checked in a lab tenant and there is no option to contain a managed device, only isolate

Device 2 is unmanaged so you can only contain this device.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-endpoint/respond-machine-alerts#isolate-devices-from-the-network

Device 1: Isolate device and Initiate Automated Investigation only
Device 2: Contain device only

Device 1: Since it's a managed device, you isolate the device, perform an automated investigation, and release it from isolation once remediated. Isolating keep connectivity with Defender for Endpoint. There's no need to contain when you've already isolated the device.

Device 2: For unmanaged devices, you can only contain them. Containing them will block incoming and outgoing connections to managed Windows 10 and Windows Server 2019+ devices (which meets the criteria asked in this question)

Device1: Important note from question â€¢ Do NOT affect the ability to control managed devices. Isolate device affect this ability! I go with Initiate Automated Investigation only
Device2: Contain device (When you have identified an unmanaged device that is compromised or potentially compromised, you might want to contain that device from the network to prevent the potential attack from moving laterally across the network.)
Source: 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-endpoint/respond-machine-alerts

comments.content:
that is correct
Device 1: Isolate device and Initiate Automated Investigation only
Device 2: Contain device only

discussion.content:
I would say the given answer is correct: According tho this explanation Isolation suits the requirements better, yes?

Isolation
Purpose: Completely disconnects the device from the network.
Effect: The device cannot communicate with any other devices or services, except for maintaining a connection to the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint service.
Use Case: Ideal for stopping all network activity from a compromised device to prevent any further malicious actions.
Containment
Purpose: Restricts the deviceâ€™s network communication.
Effect: Limits the deviceâ€™s ability to interact with other devices and services, but it still maintains essential connectivity, including to the Defender for Endpoint service.
Use Case: Useful for reducing the risk of malware spreading or other threats while still allowing some level of monitoring and management.
In summary, isolation is more severe and cuts off almost all network communication, while containment is less restrictive and allows for some controlled communication.

Device2:

 Management State: Discovered by Microsoft Defender for Endpoint and unmanaged.
 Operating System: Linux.

For Device2, since it's unmanaged:

 Containing and investigating might be limited in scope since the device is not fully onboarded.

Recommended Action:

 Isolate device only:
 This is the most critical action for an unmanaged device. By isolating the device, you prevent it from infecting managed devices without needing to worry about losing control over it, as it's unmanaged anyway.
If Linux device is not onboarded how can It be isolated?

Selected Answer: A
Regarding "endpoint security policies", the role should be Security Admin, as per this link:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-endpoint/mde-security-settings-management

"The Endpoint Security Policies page in Microsoft Defender XDR is available only for users with the security administrator role in Microsoft Defender XDR. Any other user role, such as Security Reader, cannot access the portal. When a user has the required permissions to view policies in the Microsoft Defender portal, the data is presented based on Intune permissions. If the user is in scope for Intune role-based access control, it applies to the list of policies presented in the Microsoft Defender portal. We recommend granting security administrators with the Intune built-in role, "Endpoint Security Manager" to effectively align the level of permissions between Intune and Microsoft Defender XDR."

Selected Answer: A
Security Administrator is correct answer 
Operator has less privileges - View, investigate, and respond to active threats to your Microsoft 365 users, devices, and content. For more information, see Security Operator.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-office-365/mdo-portal-permissions

Selected Answer: A
Remember that the Security Administrator role is focused on configuration and settings management. As soon as you see managing rules or policies in the question, that answer should be Security Administrator.

The Security Operator role focuses on the day-to-day operations like viewing and investigating alerts (think of L1 SOC analyst)

Selected Answer: A
Security Administrator (Option A):

 This role allows full management of security-related features across Microsoft 365, including the ability to manage security settings, policies, alerts, and more. However, this role grants broad permissions that go beyond just managing Microsoft Defender XDR custom detection rules and Endpoint security policies.

Security Operator (Option B):

 This role focuses more on handling alerts, investigating incidents, and responding to threats. It provides access to review and remediate alerts but doesn't allow managing custom detection rules or security policies.
Security Admin because the operator can't change or modify anything only read

One of the following roles is required for Defender for Office 365 

Manage alerts
Security admin

if its O365 then its Secuirty Admin
I think it should be B:Security Operator

Selected Answer: B
B. Security Operator

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that uses Microsoft Defender XDR and contains a user named User1.

You need to ensure that User1 can manage Microsoft Defender XDR custom detection rules and Endpoint security policies. The solution must follow the principle of least privilege.

Which role should you assign to User1?

HOTSPOT
-

You have the resources shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You have an Azure subscription that uses Microsoft Defender for Cloud.

You need to use Defender for Cloud to protect VM1 and Server1. The solution must meet the following requirements:

â€¢ Support Advanced Threat Protection and vulnerability assessment.
â€¢ Register each SQL Server 2022 instance as a SQL virtual machine.
â€¢ Minimize implementation and administrative effort.

What should you deploy to each server? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content: Correct answer

Correct
AMA is used to collect monitoring data from Azure and non-Azure resources

- Azure Monitor Agent replaces the legacy LA agent.
- LA agent has been deprecated, stops support at August 31, 2024

To meet the requirements for protecting VM1 and Server1 with Microsoft Defender for Cloud, you should deploy the following:

VM1:
The Azure Monitor Agent and an Azure virtual machine extension.

Server1:
The Azure Monitor Agent and an Azure virtual machine extension

This setup will support Advanced Threat Protection and vulnerability assessment, register each SQL Server 2022 instance as a SQL virtual machine, and minimize implementation and administrative effort

I don't agree with the given answer

For VM1:
Deploy The Azure Monitor Agent and an Azure virtual machine extension. This setup will support Advanced Threat Protection and vulnerability assessment, and it will allow you to register the SQL Server 2022 instance as a SQL virtual machine with minimal implementation and administrative effort.


For Server1:
Implement The Log Analytics agent and an Azure virtual machine extension. This will also support Advanced Threat Protection and vulnerability assessment, and it will enable you to register the SQL Server 2022 instance as a SQL virtual machine, aligning with the goal of minimizing implementation and administrative effort.

comments.content:
The Azure Monitor Agent (AMA) supersede the Log Analytics agent. The AMA replaces the Log Analytics agent (also known as Microsoft Monitor Agent (MMA) and OMS) for Windows and Linux machines, in Azure and non-Azure environments, including on-premises and third-party clouds.
The Log Analytics agent will be retired on August 31, 2024

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Sentinel workspace that contains a custom workbook named Workbook1.

You need to create a visual based on the SecurityEvent table. The solution must meet the following requirements:

â€¢ Identify the number of security events ingested during the past week.
â€¢ Display the count of events by day in a timechart.

What should you add to Workbook1?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A query allows you to retrieve specific data from the SecurityEvent table.
You can write a query that filters events based on the past weekâ€™s timestamp and aggregates the count of events by day.
The timechart visualization will display this aggregated data over time, showing the event count trends.
A is correct
query seems to be correct
